stream_context.summary: Kaze spent the session polishing the overworld section linked to "Quest 4 – the Zoo": rebuilding a smoother 3-D bridge, prototyping a forest made of 2-D tree walls plus 3-D foreground trees, and checking real-hardware performance.  He also reviewed beta-test feedback and brainstormed a new "trophy room" building.

development_findings.summary: Penguin NPCs lag one frame; Kaze traced the bug to the roll parameter not being factored into movement.
development_findings.quote: It looks like roll is not factored in and that's the issue.

development_findings.summary: The old timed plane mission will be replaced by a damage-based challenge: reach the end while minimizing hits.
development_findings.quote: The goal will be to get to the end without taking as much damage instead of the time limit.

development_findings.summary: A whimsical NPC that throws the player at a star re-uses the exact plane-physics code from the Super Mario Land retro section, saving effort across two areas.
development_findings.quote: It is literally the same code, just different visuals.

development_findings.summary: Rebuilt the overworld bridge with a Bezier curve to remove sharp steps and upgraded it to full 3-D; railings will be added later.
development_findings.quote: See how steppy this bridge is? I don't like it. This new bridge will be so much smoother.

development_findings.summary: Quest 4 beta test showed good overall design but serious bugs and an unpopular plane mission; Kaze now believes it can become a strong level after fixes.
development_findings.quote: The level overall seems decent except the bugs sucked and the plane mission sucked, so I think we can make a good game out of Quest 4.

development_findings.summary: Introduced a "trophy building" concept (idea from Biobak): collected mini-achievements appear as trophies; adjacent darkened trophies give hints, encouraging return visits without granting stars.
development_findings.quote: You collect one trophy and you get two hints for the next two trophies.

development_findings.summary: Forest solution: back layer of flat billboard trees plus two rows of simple low-poly 3-D trees; vertex colors and new canopy textures reduce mismatch while maintaining N64 performance (32–50 FPS confirmed on hardware).
development_findings.quote: Honestly, on N64 this looks even more like a real forest… we’re fine.

development_findings.summary: Added sound-composer tool; Badub can now build SFX such as new rotor noises directly inside the ROM.
development_findings.quote: With the sound composer I made, Badub is able to make sound effects.

development_findings.summary: Major engine optimisation complete; only smaller items like the custom operating system remain.
development_findings.quote: All the big stuff is done. There's just some small things like the operating system that I still want to do.

development_findings.summary: Built a neuro-evolution framework inside Mario 64 to train an AI player; sees future potential for content or tech demos.
development_findings.quote: I felt like making a neuroevolution Mario 64 machine learning thing… now I have a thing that can train an AI inside Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: Everdrive X7 currently fails to boot the hack; Kaze suspects the problem lies in his code and plans a fix.
development_findings.quote: The X7 had an issue where it couldn't run my mod, but that might as well also be an issue in my mod and not of the X7.

development_findings.summary: Graphics bugs noted: lighthouse texture shows wrong colour when WRITE_ALL off; decals render with black backgrounds unless WRITE_ALL enabled.
development_findings.quote: All my decals have a black background… write all fixes it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dismisses FPGA N64 clones for consumers, believing emulators are superior and free hardware samples are expected for honest reviews.
context_findings.quote: I firmly believe if someone does not send me a free copy of the N64 FPGA, they're doing some shady shit and their FPGA is probably garbage.

context_findings.summary: Squarespace sponsorship funds bi-weekly videos, and a phone sponsor allowed a genuinely positive review without obligation.
context_findings.quote: As long as Squarespace pays I'm probably gonna make a video every two weeks.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy on programming: good developers care about control, not language hype; languages with overhead are "garbage."
context_findings.quote: The only people that care about which programming language you use are people that are not very good at programming.

context_findings.summary: Shows playful self-deprecation and frustration (e.g., blender rage noises) but high productivity—finished tasks then built an AI tool on a Sunday.
context_findings.quote: I kind of try to invoke my inner child after breaking his iPad when I get upset at Blender.

context_findings.summary: Thinks social-media algorithms intentionally radicalise users for retention; distrusts AI-generated commercial art.
context_findings.quote: They're not turning people into Nazis for no reason.

biobak.summary: Proposed the overworld "trophy building" that tracks side achievements and provides hints; Kaze accepted the idea.
biobak.quote: We could add a little trophy room… NPC telling you there's no star at all. Yeah, I'm kind of on board with that Biobak.

biobak.summary: Gave feedback on environmental assets such as benches, special railings and bridge aesthetics.

badub.summary: Using Kaze's new sound-composer, Badub produced rotor sound effects for the plane section.
badub.quote: With the sound composer I made, Badub is able to make sound effects.

zeina.summary: Provides high-resolution (640×640) hand-drawn textures; Kaze plans to source her canopy artwork to improve tree crowns.
zeina.quote: Maybe Zeina still has HD versions of her textures, then we could use those.

key_stories.title: Plane Mission Overhaul
key_stories.summary: Beta testers disliked the timed airplane section in Quest 4. Kaze decided mid-stream to redesign it so players must survive environmental damage instead of racing a clock.
key_stories.challenge: Timed plane mission felt unfun and was flagged in testing.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed live, opted to switch objective from speed to health preservation.
key_stories.outcome: New design direction set; code and level tweaks scheduled.
key_stories.key_quote: The plane mission sucked, so the goal will be to get to the end without taking as much damage instead of the time limit.

key_stories.title: Birth of the Trophy Room
key_stories.summary: Biobak suggested a non-star "trophy" hall for mini-achievements. Kaze refined the concept, adding progressive hints and a two-floor layout.
key_stories.challenge: Overworld lacked engaging buildings and long-term optional goals.
key_stories.process: Live ideation with chat; weighed player confusion, decided on readable blacked-out trophies giving hints.
key_stories.outcome: Idea added to task list for prototyping.
key_stories.key_quote: You collect one trophy and you get two hints for the next two trophies.

key_stories.title: From Flat to Forest
key_stories.summary: The overworld’s blank backdrop needed depth. Kaze experimented with 2-D billboards plus low-poly 3-D trees, crafted new canopy textures, and tested on real N64 to ensure acceptable FPS.
key_stories.challenge: Create dense jungle visuals without killing performance.
key_stories.process: Iterated textures in GIMP/Photoshop, adjusted vertex colours, arranged multi-row parallax trees, verified RDP load on hardware.
key_stories.outcome: Prototype forest runs at 32–50 FPS; colour-matching and texture polish remain.
key_stories.key_quote: Honestly, on N64 this looks even more like a real forest… we’re fine.
